[0] https://github.com/openstack/airship-shipyard/blob/6d01f3f07bd031b9ceae463e0020f3688441de5e/src/bin/shipyard_airflow/shipyard_airflow/control/helpers/design_reference_helper.py#L39
I believe so. Good find.
result
When referencing deployment-status here I was referencing the document, not the status field. I will update this comment to make it more clear.

I am confused with the intention here. We already have a way of checking the status in line 157 so why do we have a kind of duplication in line 180.

Is the intention here to track the "status" or the "result"? If it's just "status" then we can reuse definition from Line 157. if it's result then we can remove the definiton at line 180.

Also if we are interested in knowing the final result of the deployment then it has to be either "success" or "failed" and not "pending". For eg- If the deployment status is still "pending" even after the specified timeout period then result should indicate as "failed".

The intention here was to provide a simple mapping from the lifecycle of the action to the desired "status" field data in the deployment-status document.

I would expect a timed-out action to have a status of "completed" and a result of "failed"
This looks confusing
Agreed, I will update these function names to make a little more sense.

This could be -  
"DesignRefHelper().get_design_reference_href(self.committed_rev_id)"

Could possibly remove this function and use it directly on line 762.

For me it's just personal preference to put a thin wrapper around using DesignRefHelper in order to generate the URL. I was also worried that putting this all on one line would look a little too dense, but I'm cool with knocking it down to one line if that isn't an issue.

Do we still need both the "status" and "result"? If yes then i guess status "document/data" needs to be seperate than the "result" data.
For eg- In this implementation, if the status is "processing" then result is "pending" which could be confusing as result should indicate the final output of the deployment ie, either "success" or "failure"

I'm not sure I 100% understood what you meant by "i guess status 'document/data' needs to be seperate than the 'result' data."

It is desired that status and result are separate fields.
The idea behind status being "whether or not the SY action was completed or in-progress"
The idea behind result being "whether or not the SY action was successful"
That being said, I'm open to what the potential values of status and result should be. I chose things that made sense to me, but that doesn't mean it makes sense to everyone.

This looks important, do we really only want to check for these old keys if the dag isn't provided at all?

The way it's coded right now, the old keys will not overwrite a dag object given. So if you were to both provide the legacy keys and also provide the dag dict, the dag dict would take precedence.

blazar/db/sqlalchemy/utils.py.message:
I believe the fields need to be specified for the ORM to run this 3-table join efficiently. I posted a longer explanation of this in https://bugs.launchpad.net/blazar/+bug/1838025. Example below of fields to join:

.join(models.Lease, 
      models.Lease.id == models.Reservation.lease_id)
.join(models.ComputeHostAllocation,
      models.ComputeHostAllocation.reservation_id == models.

SQLAlchemy should be using foreign keys to detect how best to join tables together: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/tutorial.html#querying-with-joins

tackerclient/v1_0/client.py.message: why all changes here, as it(tackerclient cli) already depricated.

Dharmendra: OSC command invokes make_client which can return only one proxy client based on the requested version. Hence, the vnf package APIs are implemented in the same client using the facade design pattern so that it can still support the previous OSC commands along with the newly added VNF package command.

As mentioned by Shubham, the second option is to implement these commands in the openstackclient along with the openstacksdk changes.

so we have two design choices, the one implemented in this patch and second one is OpenStackclient + openstacksdk.

1)I have referred the existing design which was followed while adding osc cli support for vnf, vnfd, vim etc. commands for ex(tackerclient\osc\v1\vnfm\vnf.py), in that case also  same client file  is used (tackerclient/v1_0/client.py) 

2)In case if we use client from openstacksdk (https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675604/) instead of tackerclient( tackerclient.v1_0.client.Client)
then we need to change client from make_client() method from this file tackerclient\osc\plugin.py
and with above change existing osc commands like
"openstack vim create" will not work.

3)because of this reason we came up with this solution.
with this changes 
openstack vnfpack create will work
tacker vnfpack create won't work

deployment/zaqar/zaqar-container-puppet..message: shouldn't this be chmod, chown, touch? or chown, chmod, touch?

I went with chmod, touch, chown because it will set the sticky bit on the directory making sure all new files from this point are using inheriting the set group ownership, I then create the log file if it doesn't exist, which at that point would have an ownership setting of `root:zaqar`, and then set the ownership to `zaqar:zaqar` for all files within the directory. While the zaqar-server.log file is the only file I'm currently worried about, I wanted to make sure any and all files in this directory have the expected ownership and the sticky bit is simply being used as a protective measure.
we might want as well to extend this fix for the neighbor services following the same chown -R pattern

tools/fixup_stuff.sh.message:
I have this comment in my systemd apparmor using Leap 15.0 
# systemd maps 'restart' to 'stop; start' which means removing AppArmor confinement
# from running processes (and not being able to re-apply it later).
# Upstream systemd developers refused to implement an option that allows overriding
# this behaviour, therefore we have to make ExecStop a no-op to error out on the
# safe side.

Interesting, where do you see that comment?

What do you propose as a solution for systems which don't have aa-teardown?

You can see the comment here
https://build.opensuse.org/package/view_file/openSUSE:Leap:15.2/apparmor/apparmor.service?expand=1

This was the patch that introduced the stop behaviour https://gitlab.com/apparmor/apparmor/merge_requests/81

And the release notes explain the rationale https://www.suse.com/releasenotes/x86_64/SUSE-SLES/15/#fate-325343

My understanding is that you can safely add the `systemctl stop apparmor`, it will disable apparmor in previous SLES versions and will be a no-op in newer ones.

I will keep the previous if and add this additional check
Thanks for the info.  A no-op is no good otherwise haproxy/dnsmasq will still break.  I'll make it use aa-teardown if and only if it's available, and call stop in all cases.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This seems like a lot less work than re-calculating the mappings on revert doesn't it? Save off the port->allocation provider mapping on resize in the migration context and then on revert pull it out. I know we're getting late to make that kind of change, but how hard would it be or would we be able to do it later (though doing it later means RPC changes on the MigrationContext object).

When we do the forward move then the mapping calculation can be replaced with the usage of the new placement api version 1.34 [1]. But for the revert we already lost the original allocation dict returned by the scheduler. However as the allocation key is in the binding-profile, neutron multiple binding api could be used to remember the source host binding including the source host mapping. I think this is what will happen in the live migration code path for the bandwidth feature. But for cold migrate nova does not use  that neutron API yet. 

Honestly I don't really want to add a new object and RPC change to the series in Train days before the feature freeze. Not just because it is questionable if we can land it, but because I think the proper solution is to use the multiple binding neutron API and let neutron remember the mapping. Also the current re-calculating solution is only expensive for instances that are using the bandwidth feature. So this not affect the majority of the deployments. 

I do have a TODO and intention to start using placement 1.34 in the feature and also to at least try to use the multiple binding api for cold migrate and resize. So that nova can fully get rid of the mapping calculation code. This was the original agreement a year ago that the mapping calculation code is temporary in nova.

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/placement-api-microversion-history.html#request-group-mappings-in-allocation-candidates

And this really shouldn't happen anyway, right? Meaning if our min compute and pinning checks are in place, a resize of a server with ports with requested resources shouldn't be allowed to even get this far, so to get here, the operator would have had to do something like upgrade the computes to Train with compute rpc unpinned, the user performs a resize, then the compute rpc is pinned and then the user tries to revert the resize and things blow up. That shouldn't happen unless someone screws up the upgrade.

Now I got it. The difference is that the problem what grenade hit is that RequestSpec is None. While the problem that could not happen is that the RequestSpec is None _and_ we would need a non empty provider_mapping. The second cannot happen as that would fail the forward move already.

But it happened in the grenade run last night. So either grande does not do the upgrade well. Or we are mistaken.


I don't think this is really high coupling. We don't get the request spec so we don't calculate the pinning. Later on if the pinning would be needed but it is not provided then we blow. The _update_port_binding_for_instance() has no problem with provider_mapping=None if there is no port with resource request attached to the instance. 

I think what this solution does is it only enforces that there is a provider_mapping if that is really needed.

I meant we shouldn't hit the PortUpdateFailed because we shouldn't be migrating an instance with a port that has resource requests to begin with. The grenade failure was correct because nova is configured (in grenade) with [upgrade_levels]/compute=auto and since there is a stein compute, it adjusts and pins the compute rpc api version to stein, so that's why on revert the request spec wasn't passed down to the compute and we blew up.

Hi Deepak, sorry for the slow response. Ok, I get your point and I didn't fully consider the implications of a mixed SR-IOV and DPDK use case. so, thank you for clarifying. I agree with the approach you have taken.

Georg, when I test it locally, I see that the script does exit if the kernel interface doesn't exist. 

ubuntu@u1604:~/test$ ./script.sh
+ export src_nic=ensfg4
+ src_nic=ensfg4
++ get_ip_address_from_interface ensfg4
++ local interface=ensfg4
+++ awk '{ print $4; exit }'
+++ ip -4 -o addr s ensfg4
+++ awk -F / '{print $1}'
Device "ensfg4" does not exist.
++ local ip=
++ '[' -z '' ']'
++ exit 1
+ ip=

------

Also the things got bit complicated by the fact that we are trying to deploy it for a shared profile scenario, i.e. sriov+ovs-dpdk, where any specific VF interfaces is being used for ovs-dpdk. So in such a case, the way it works it that in nics section user can either provide nic of a vf directly or he can provide the nic of physical NIC and the vf number he wants to use. The latter case is useful because if sriov-agent is configuring the VFs then operator may not know the PCI id of that VF NIC beforehand.

Due to above, even in rerun case, PF interface shall still be visible as its the VF NIC which has been bound to DPDK.

So we have following possibilities:-

1. User provides PCI of NIC to be bound to DPDK (plain ovs-dpdk case and shared profile case when user provides PCI of VF): 
    - In case of rerun, either the interface itself shouldn't exist, in which case the dpdk bridge should hv a valid IP, or if it exists then it should hv a valid IP...

2.  User provides PCI of PF (shared profile case):
    - In case of rerun, the interface will always exist because its the VF PCI thats bound to DPDK not PF. So in this case either the interface should hv a valid IP or the dpdk bridge should hv a valid IP. If none as a valid IP then its a failure case.


So to take care of all these cases, I think following solution caters to both scenarios:- "If IP is not found on the interface or if the interface itself is not found then check if the dpdk bridge has got an IP already? If yes then treat it as success case. If both the interface as well as the bridge don;t hv IP then this is an error scenario"

The current implementation in my patchset is as per above philosophy. Please check and let me know if you see some scenario is being missed here?

Georg, this is required in the case when suppose we are running the chart second time. In the first run, IP was migrated to bridge and it was flushed from the nic. Now if we restart the pod then it will fail on these lines, instead, it should first check if IP exist on the bridge? If yes then that should be treated as a success case. Thats what I am trying to do here and this part has been tested ok for all the various scenarios.....

oh, yes, you are absolutely right about the case when re-running the script: It should not exit.

However, for clarity: when re-running the script, it does not exit because the given interface, which is a kernel interface, does not exist anymore; it was assigned to DPDK during the previous run. Because of this, the "if -n $name" condition is not met and the entire IP migration logic is skipped.

I believe the script should in fact exit with an error if
 i) the kernel interface still exists (i.e., the NIC was not bound to DPDK yet) and
ii) has no valid IP assigned

This is a configuration problem and should be caught. That was the intention of the "echo" in the get_ip_... functions.

Still, if I miss anything (again), please let me know.

{
    "quota_set": {
        "id": "a7090a26bc554d93aa845a4d41808251",
        "volumes": 10,

        "volumes_lvmdriver-1": -1,

Felipe,

Thank you so much for your explanation.
I got JSON-Schema allows additional properties with specific type by using this case.
Then, that means Cinder will add more properties without writing them on https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=show-quotas-for-a-project-detail#quota-sets-extension-os-quota-sets right?

The additionalProperties keyword is used to control the handling of extra stuff, that is, properties whose names are not listed in the properties keyword. By default any additional properties are allowed.

The additionalProperties keyword may be either a boolean or an object. If additionalProperties is a boolean and set to false, no additional properties will be allowed.

...

If additionalProperties is an object, that object is a schema that will be used to validate any additional properties not listed in properties.

https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference/object.html

Reason why it is here is because the additional properties all have type integer, so it is more explicit enforcement to add an object instead of a boolean, because boolean just says: "Yes there are more properties" but object says: "Yes there are more properties that must pass this object schema".

deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml.message: you're not merging anything here, you don't need the map_merge, since your list only has one item.

Our list will have multiple items like so:

  CephOSDConfigOverrides:
    osd_heartbeat_min_size: 9000
    osd_snap_trim_priority: 1

As such map_merge is needed, otherwise they show up in one line on ceph.conf like this:

[osd]
    {osd_heartbeat_min_size: 9000, osd_snap_trim_priority: 1}

Instead of like this:

[osd]
    osd_heartbeat_min_size: 9000
    osd_snap_trim_priority: 1

hooks/ceph_hooks.py.message: Would this not risk a operator to inadvertently enable the ``pg_autoscaler`` module by adding a monitor to their existing cluster?
Indeed, if I user upgrades a pre-Nautilus cluster to Nautlius, and then adds a monitor, if would trigger this code on the new monitor.

So you are deferring the action to a different unit, should this then just be a informational or debug message?

If the unit you would expect to be able to do this fails an error, or even charm status change would of course be in order.

Does "the last monitor" mean the leader monitor from Ceph's perspective?

The last monitor is required, because prior to ALL monitors running Nautilus, this command returns non-zero with "Error ENOENT: all mgr daemons do not support module pg_autoscaler', pass --force to force enablement" , so we will only succeed at enabling this feature on the final monitor to be upgraded.

It is also possible to pass a `--force` option to the command to allow it to be enabled early, but I'm not sure what the negative consequences of running a module like that in a mixed cluster is so I don't want to use that option.

Regarding lowering the log level, that sounds reasonable, I'll update it to info

So, if I read this right, the only situation where the ``autotune`` monitor key would exist prior to getting here is if the config-changed hook has been executed with the config value of ``pg-autotune`` set to 'true'.

How would this change the behavior described in patch set 24 on a upgraded cluster where that config has not been set by the operator?

Perhaps a key needs to be set in the charm upgrade hook, ``check_for_upgrade`` helper or something similar so we can know whether this is a new Nautilius installation or a upgraded one?

This is done during cluster bootstrap, and is stored in the ceph mon's KV store. During the initial bootstrap, a decision is made about enabling the autotuner, and that decision is stored in the KV store. In the event of an upgrade / expansion, the key will already exist (because we have existing mons) and will return the existing value.

neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py.message:
first of all, notify() method is already deprecated and publish() should be used instead.
And secondly, such notification is already send in _check_subnet_not_used() function, which is called in L1061
Thanks, hadn't spotted that. I'll remove it.

According to the bug description, what we need is to create a network context before the deletion of the segments. But here you are implementing a BEFORE_EVENT for the subnets. I don't see the relationship here.

From the commit message:

A similar change has been made for subnets, both to keep the pattern consistent and avoid any similar issues.

In this path we don't get a BEFORE_DELETE event for subnet deletion, since it's called from delete_subnet rather than _delete_subnet.
_delete_subnet doesn't call BEFORE_DELETE, so added it here.

neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py.message: Can't You simply use higher priority for this handler to make sure that this will always be called first?
Ok, but is there a benefit to that approach vs. this one?
By this: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/callbacks/priority_group.py#L19, you can choose zero or 1 as highest priority.

I considered doing that. The problem with priorities is that they're a bit arbitrary - how do I pick a number that ensures I'll always run before other handlers that might modify the network? With before_delete I know I'll always have an unmodified copy of the network.

That said, I'm sure you're more familiar with this code than I am, so if there's a good reason not to do this I'm open to using priorities.
just a question: why this change? This won't interfere with _subnet_mech_context because those are different contexts

See the last paragraph of the commit message. Without this, the unit tests failed when deleting networks, and deleting subnets belonging to that network. It uses the same context, so after the subnet deletion is finished the NetworkContext gets replaced with a SubnetContext.

I'm ok with this change (this is cleaner).

one nit: registry priority should be something generally available (neutron_lib.callbacks.priority_group) for any other project (out-of-tree ml2 driver, for example).
Yes, I know. This could be for next versions, IMO this is not a blocker at all.

Are you saying there should be some constant defined in neutron-lib for the value zero?

That would require a new neutron-lib release, so I guess it's too late to do that for Train?

nova/api/metadata/vendordata_dynamic.py.message:
Hm, according to the novajoin code, the response should be application/json when a Fault is raised:

https://github.com/openstack/novajoin/blob/e8b18c4bd44ea86cbbedfdf9a9f0f7f7718c9c56/novajoin/base.py#L728

but, also according to ksa code, if the response doesn't have the expected format (top-level "error" key):

https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/blob/38cd5fc6c39c38a51c11683884caf9696ce5f367/keystoneauth1/exceptions/http.py#L407

it should show a message "Unrecognized schema in response body." in our log here, but we don't see that in the logs. I don't understand why/how the log message isn't getting the detailed message from novajoin. :(
You're trying to append to a tuple here. Not sure where to look in the CI logs, but I assume L120 is not triggering or you would see that bit blow up?

Oh, oops, I see now.

It's not something we can see in upstream CI (I don't know how to do it yet) but what I meant in my other comment is that we have a log sample [1] but it contains no error message from the vendordata service (novajoin) even though novajoin is raising an exception with a detailed message.

I looked through the ksa code trying to figure out how it decides what to put in the from_response message and what I found so far I would expect it to say "Unrecognized schema in response body" but it doesn't. So I'm clearly missing something about how either novajoin is returning an error over http or how ksa (as a client) creates the exception message on the other side.

Going to have to figure out how to recreate this in upstream CI to see what's going on, probably.

I'll plug all this into the commit message when I merge it back

Think we might be getting terminology mixed up here. The filter doesn't know anything about PCPUs or VCPUs or anything else from placement land. It only knows 'HostState' and 'RequestSpec' objects, the former of which contains a 'NUMATopology' object (via the 'numa_topology' field) which we attempt to fit the 'InstanceNUMATopology' object provided by the latter (via its own 'numa_topology' field) against.

Sooo...it's not that the filter won't look at PCPUs or VCPUs. Rather, it'll look at the 'NUMATopology.pcpuset' field, and behave differently depending on whether this is Train with new-style config, Train with old-style config, or Stein:

- For Train compute nodes with new-style config, 'NUMATopology.pcpuset' will be explictly set to the value of '[compute] cpu_dedicated_set' or, if only '[compute] cpu_dedicated_set' is configured, 'None' (it's nullable) by the virt driver so the calls to 'hardware.numa_fit_instance_to_host' in the 'NUMATopologyFilter' will fail.

- For Train compute nodes with old-style config, 'NUMATopology.pcpuset' will be set to the same value as 'NUMATopology.cpuset' by the virt driver.

- For Stein compute nodes, 'NUMATopology.pcpuset' will be unset and we'll detect this in 'hardware.numa_fit_instance_to_host' and simply set it to the same value as 'NUMATopology.cpuset'.

Note that we could probably unify the last two cases and simply not set 'pcpuset' if the new-style config isn't present, but it makes the virt driver code a bit uglier.

Thinking about your question actually answered a question I had about what limits are for: they're for when allocation ratios are set centrally on the controller only, and not on each compute host, right?

So yeah, we should pass them to the claim. Done.

They're calculated by the controller and passed down to the compute to tell it what to claim. That is partially for the behavior where ratios are centrally-managed, but also for the case where you used to be able to just disable a scheduler filter and cause all the computes to stop accounting for that thing. So, if you don't want to schedule on Disk (because it's never been right), you can disable that filter and that will cause computes to never do the Disk part of the claim stuff and just assume things will be fine.

In more general terms, it's the way the scheduler communicates to the compute what it picked.

> This api should return True almost always. Return False only for
 > relax_scale_validation with older version.
 > This is not the case right now.

Here is my opinion:

If we default the return value of this API to True, then _set_attrs_if_supported() is no difference from _set_attrs_if_specified(), for any attrs unknon to this API, and the safekeeping property of this api is lost.

From the design point of view, this api checks if a "version dependent" attr meets the requirement to be passed in. Since we can't enum every non-version dependent attr in this api (which is out of the scope and unnecessary), it should be defendent and default to false. In the end, it's the developer's responisbility to use the correct API to set attributes. 

_attr_supported() in each resource def serves as a registry to safely can clearly indicate all version dependent attrs related to said resource, and their perspective minimum version requirements. For any attr to reach _attr_supported(), it is supposedly to go through _set_attrs_if_supported(), and the name explains itself: why would someone use "if supported" if there is no support dependency, and "if specified" meets the need better? 

Please leave some comment regarding this. Thank you.

OK, here it is my understanding. The list in _set_attrs_if_supported contains the parameters that need to check NSX version. Therefore when developers add an attr in this list, they should also implement the corresponding check in _attr_supported(). Is that right? If that's the case, I think the default False makes sense.
